text.p: Danish bank Unidanmark announced a fall in 1996 profit on Wednesday, sending its share down six crowns, to 349 at 1205 GMT.
"Unidanmark's result was a little lower than general expectations but what strikes us is that the dividend has not been raised," a dealer who declined to be named told Reuters.
"This is definitely going to disappoint foreign investors," he added.
Unidanmark, Denmark's second-biggest bank, reported 1996 net profits down to 2.025 billion crowns from 1995's 2.116 billion crowns and left its dividend unchanged at 10 percent.

Profit before tax and extraordinary items, at 2.801 billion crowns, was lower than the average of analysts' expectations of 2.912 billion crowns, although well above the most pessimistic forecast of 2.016 billion.

Analysts were generally disappointed at lower than expected 1996 securities and foreign exchange profits of 954 million crowns against 1995's 1.157 billion, although net interest and fees income rose overall.
The Unidanmark report said that operating costs rose last year to 5.822 billion crowns from 5.639 in 1995.

It said that of the 183 million crown increase in costs, 144 million was incurred in the aquisition of Swedish-Swiss Asea Brown Bovery stockbroking business and the subsequent establishment of Aros Securities as a Nordic investment banking unit of Unidanmark. --Stig Pedersen, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33969652
